unnormalised: E-commerce in India has witnessed a significant upswing, but many consumers still grapple with understanding the nuances of online transactions. I’ve been asked about the common numerical representations one might encounter while engaging in online shopping. Let's explore the prevalent formats and scenarios.
normalised: E-commerce in India has witnessed a significant upswing, but many consumers still grapple with understanding the nuances of online transactions. I’ve been asked about the common numerical representations one might encounter while engaging in online shopping. Let's explore the prevalent formats and scenarios.

unnormalised: Firstly, order IDs are crucial for tracking purchases. These are usually alphanumeric strings, often a mix of letters and numerals. For example, you might see an order ID like “ODR4567890123IN”. The "IN" typically denotes the transaction originated from India. Another variation could be "2024/ABC/12345", where the prefix indicates the year the order was placed. These identifiers are system-generated and unique to each transaction.
normalised: Firstly, order I-Ds are crucial for tracking purchases. These are usually alphanumeric strings, often a mix of letters and numerals. For example, you might see an order I-D like “O-D-R four five six seven eight nine zero one two three I-N”. The "I-N" typically denotes the transaction originated from India. Another variation could be "two thousand and twenty four slash A-B-C slash one two three four five", where the prefix indicates the year the order was placed. These identifiers are system-generated and unique to each transaction.

unnormalised: Secondly, pricing is represented in a variety of ways. While the standard is "₹" followed by the amount, you'll also see "Rs." or even just "INR". So, a product priced at ₹5,999 may also be displayed as Rs 5999 or INR 5999. Discounts are often displayed as percentages, e.g., "20% off" or "Save 15%". Furthermore, “Buy 2 Get 1 Free” is a common promotional tactic.
normalised: Secondly, pricing is represented in a variety of ways. While the standard is "rupee" followed by the amount, you'll also see "rupees" or even just "I-N-R". So, a product priced at rupee five thousand nine hundred and ninety nine may also be displayed as rupees five thousand nine hundred and ninety nine or I-N-R five thousand nine hundred and ninety nine. Discounts are often displayed as percentages, e.g., "twenty percent off" or "save fifteen percent". Furthermore, “buy two get one free” is a common promotional tactic.

unnormalised: Thirdly, shipping costs also involve numerical data. You may encounter "Free shipping on orders above ₹499" or a fixed shipping charge, say "Shipping: ₹50". Some platforms offer expedited shipping, with charges like "Express Delivery: ₹100 extra". Estimated delivery times are often displayed as a range of dates, for example, "Arriving between 10/11/2024 - 12/11/2024".

unnormalised: Fourthly, payment gateways often use numerical codes for transaction status. A successful transaction might show a reference number like "TXN ID: 9876543210". A failed transaction might display an error code like "Error 404" or "Code 500", along with a specific numerical error message related to the bank. OTPs (One-Time Passwords) are essential for verification, often a 6-digit number sent to your registered mobile number.
